description: Federal statutory floor conditioning state eligibility for child welfare funding. These statutes do not grant removal authority; they constrain and condition state action and funding under the Supremacy Clause.
copyright: Project Milk Carton 501(c)(3) - All Rights Reserved

requirements.name: Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act (CAPTA)
requirements.constitutional_alignment: Fourteenth Amendment procedural due process; First Amendment petition rights
requirements.description: Establishes minimum federal standards for state child abuse reporting, intake, and oversight systems as a condition of receiving CAPTA state grants.
key_provisions: Mandatory reporter categories must be defined by state law
Statewide intake and reporting systems required
Good-faith immunity for reporters
Confidentiality protections for reports and records
Citizen Review Panels for independent oversight
Public disclosure of child abuse fatalities
Data submission to NCANDS
constitutional_limits: CAPTA does not authorize warrantless searches or removals
Reporting statutes must operate within Fourth and Fourteenth Amendment constraints
False or malicious reporting cannot override due process

requirements.name: Adoption and Safe Families Act (ASFA)
requirements.constitutional_alignment: Fourteenth Amendment procedural and substantive due process
requirements.description: Conditions Title IV-E funding on state compliance with reasonable-efforts findings, judicial oversight, and permanency timelines. ASFA does not itself create removal authority.
key_provisions: Judicial finding of reasonable efforts prior to removal unless statutory exception applies
Reasonable efforts toward reunification required
Permanency hearing within 12 months of foster placement
TPR filing when child has been in care 15 of last 22 months (with statutory exceptions)
Child safety designated as paramount concern
constitutional_limits: Safety determinations must be individualized and evidence-based
Reasonable efforts findings are subject to due process review
Funding conditions cannot override constitutional family integrity rights
requirements.funding_at_risk: Title IV-E Foster Care and Adoption Assistance

requirements.name: Social Security Act Title IV-E
requirements.constitutional_alignment: Spending Clause; Fourteenth Amendment due process
requirements.description: Primary federal reimbursement mechanism for foster care, adoption assistance, and kinship guardianship. Funding is conditioned on strict compliance with judicial and procedural safeguards.
key_provisions: Foster care maintenance payments
Adoption and guardianship assistance
Judicial determinations required for eligibility
Case plan and case review requirements
Ongoing federal audits and CFSR monitoring
constitutional_limits: Funding eligibility cannot substitute for judicial authority
Noncompliance results in funding disallowance, not retroactive authorization

requirements.name: Indian Child Welfare Act (ICWA)
requirements.constitutional_alignment: Indian Commerce Clause; Due Process; Federal trust responsibility
requirements.description: Establishes mandatory federal standards for proceedings involving Indian (Native American) children, superseding state law where applicable.
key_provisions: Tribal jurisdiction and transfer rights
Active efforts requirement (heightened standard)
Qualified expert witness testimony
Placement preferences codified
Strict notice requirements to tribes
constitutional_limits: ICWA applies only when child meets federal definition of Indian child
State courts lack discretion to ignore ICWA mandates
requirements.funding_at_risk: Title IV-E; proceedings subject to invalidation

requirements.name: Family First Prevention Services Act (FFPSA)
requirements.description: Reorients federal funding toward prevention services and family preservation, reducing reliance on congregate care.
key_provisions: IV-E funding for prevention services
Evidence-based service requirements
Kinship placement prioritization
QRTP placement limitations
constitutional_limits: Service refusal alone cannot justify removal

requirements.name: Parental Kidnapping Prevention Act (PKPA)
requirements.constitutional_alignment: Full Faith and Credit Clause; Due Process
requirements.description: Requires states to honor custody determinations from other states. In January 2025, a White House executive order directed agencies to consider applying PKPA to investigate 'sanctuary states' that facilitate custody changes for gender-affirming care.
key_provisions: States must enforce valid custody orders from other states
Home state has priority jurisdiction
Prevents forum shopping in custody disputes
Federal enforcement mechanisms available
constitutional_limits: Does not preempt state child welfare authority
Application to gender-affirming care cases contested

current_controversy.description: Conflict between states with shield laws protecting gender-affirming care and states banning it creates interstate custody battles. January 2025 executive order targets 'sanctuary states' under PKPA.
current_controversy.supreme_court_ruling: US v. Skrmetti (2025) - upheld state bans as not violating Equal Protection

citation_urls.title: Full Faith and Credit for Custody Determinations

gender_affirming_care_laws.summary: As of 2025, states are sharply divided on gender-affirming care for minors. 25 states have bans following US v. Skrmetti (2025). 11 states have 'shield' or 'sanctuary' laws protecting care. Some shield laws include custody provisions that could affect CPS jurisdiction.

provisions: California courts can take jurisdiction over children seeking gender-affirming care from ban states
Protects providers from out-of-state subpoenas
Prohibits enforcement of other states' custody orders based on gender-affirming care
Minnesota courts have jurisdiction when child present for gender-affirming care
Prohibits enforcement of out-of-state orders removing child for receiving gender-affirming care
Prohibits enforcement of other states' laws in child protection actions based on gender-affirming care
Protects minors seeking gender-affirming care from estranged parents
Host homes can provide shelter without parental notification in some cases
Requires 'good faith attempt' to reunify family
Does NOT automatically remove children from homes
Shield law protecting providers
Prohibits cooperation with out-of-state investigations
Shield law for providers and patients
Prohibits enforcement of out-of-state subpoenas
Shield law for providers
Shield law for providers
Shield protections via executive action
Shield law for providers
Shield law for providers
Shield law for providers

ban_states.texas_note: Texas directive classifies providing gender-affirming care as child abuse, potentially triggering CPS investigation and custody loss

federal_executive_action_2025.title: Protecting Children from Chemical and Surgical Mutilation
provisions: Directs agencies to investigate sanctuary states under PKPA
Targets states that 'facilitate stripping custody from parents who support healthy development'
Federal funding restrictions contemplated

trafficking_laws.summary: Federal anti-trafficking laws establish protections for victims, including minors. Safe harbor laws protect minor victims from prosecution for prostitution-related offenses.

federal_statutes.name: Trafficking Victims Protection Act (TVPA)
federal_statutes.description: Primary federal anti-trafficking law. Defines sex trafficking and labor trafficking. Creates federal crimes and victim protections.
key_provisions: Defines severe forms of trafficking in persons
Sex trafficking: recruiting by force, fraud, or coercion for commercial sex acts
Any minor induced to perform commercial sex acts is trafficking victim regardless of force/fraud/coercion
Creates T-visa for trafficking victims
Mandatory restitution for victims
Up to life imprisonment for traffickers
minor_specific_protections: No force/fraud/coercion requirement for minors under 18
Minor victims cannot consent to commercial sex
Access to services through Office for Victims of Crime

federal_statutes.name: Justice for Victims of Trafficking Act (JVTA)
federal_statutes.description: Strengthens TVPA, creates Domestic Trafficking Victims Fund, requires state child welfare agencies to develop protocols for trafficking victims.
key_provisions: Creates Domestic Trafficking Victims Fund from fines
Requires states to develop protocols for identifying trafficking victims in child welfare system
Enhanced penalties for buyers of commercial sex with minors
Clarifies minors cannot be charged with prostitution under federal law
child_welfare_requirements: State plan must include procedures for identifying trafficking among foster children
Must document and report children who run away from foster care
Must have protocols for locating children missing from care

federal_statutes.name: Frederick Douglass Trafficking Victims Prevention and Protection Reauthorization Act
federal_statutes.description: Reauthorizes TVPA with focus on child victims and runaway youth.
key_provisions: Strengthens prevention programs for at-risk youth
Enhanced training for law enforcement on child trafficking
Improved data collection on child trafficking

safe_harbor_laws.description: Safe harbor laws protect minor trafficking victims from prosecution for prostitution and related offenses, recognizing them as victims rather than criminals.
safe_harbor_laws.federal_guidance: While no federal safe harbor law exists, JVTA clarifies minors cannot be charged with prostitution under federal law. States encouraged to adopt safe harbor provisions.

states_with_safe_harbor.notes: First safe harbor law in US
Safe Harbor for Exploited Children Act

statistics.source: National Center for Missing & Exploited Children
statistics.finding: 1 in 6 endangered runaways reported to NCMEC are likely child sex trafficking victims
statistics.foster_care_connection: Of those, 86% were in foster care or group homes when they ran

required_protocols: Identify potential trafficking victims among children in care
Provide specialized services to identified victims
Report missing children to NCMEC within 24 hours
Screen runaway and homeless youth for trafficking indicators
